title: Leo Williams
text:
Hello!
I am a Master’s student in Geomatics for Environmental Management (MGEM) at the University of British Columbia, with a Bachelor of Science in Environmental Geography from Concordia University. My academic background combines environmental science, remote sensing, and geospatial analysis, with a strong focus on applying spatial tools to real-world environmental and social challenges.
I have professional and research experience in environmental management, conservation, and data analysis, including an internship with MRF (Marine Research Foundation) in Malaysia where I worked on spatio-temporal analyses to support fisheries conservation and policy. I am particularly interested in community-driven research, environmental justice, and the role of geospatial technologies in supporting equitable and sustainable decision-making.
Outside of academics, I am an avid rock climber and enjoy spending time outdoors. I value interdisciplinary work, collaboration, and using technical skills to contribute to meaningful environmental action.

Content & Deliverables
LiDAR Boulder Project
text:
This is a personal project trying to find new bouldering zones in Squamish, BC. I am using publicly available LiDAR datasets (LidarBC) to create high resolution Digital Terrain Models (DTMs). 3D renders of these DTMs allow for terrain below the forest canopy to be studied and find hidden boulders!
In order to both create the DTMs and vizualize them I rely on the lidR package in R studio.

title: LiDAR Boulder Project
text:
What it looks like
This may take a while to get running because there’s billions of points in this point cloud…
The first step is creating a DTM so we can see whats going on at the surface below the forest canopy.
Here is my DTM in 2D. You can see the areas of increased elevation where the bigger boulders are.

plot(apron_dtm)








It is way more fun, and easier to see whats going on in 3D. The biggest boulder here is the Cacodemon boulder in Squamish with loads of famous routes on it.


The same workflow can be replicated in valleys anywhere to try and find new bouldering zones.
